body.overview: Reviewed CoderAI's documentation to understand collaboration architecture

key_insights.communication_flow: OverseerAI → GitHub Issues → CoderAI → Pull Request → OverseerAI
key_insights.separation_of_concerns: Code sharing via Git, messaging via GitHub Issues
key_insights.bootstrap_process: Library code in repository, accessible to both AIs

communication_patterns.task_data_wrapper: Non-Sendable types wrapped in TaskData for Swift 6.2 compliance

git_integration.git_manager: Handles Git operations (add, commit, push, pull, status)
git_integration.worktree_manager: Manages Git worktrees for multi-AI collaboration

best_practices_learned: Always Save State - Save important state to memory after operations
Handle All Message Types - Implement handlers for task, feedback, approval, rejection, heartbeat
Use Knowledge Base - Store reusable patterns and solutions
Document Code - Always document code changes
Use Descriptive Issue Titles - Format like [TASK] Implement user authentication

clarifications: Communication flow is GitHub Issues-based, not just Git commits
Pull Requests are the formal review mechanism
Three approaches for using CoderAI code: Pull & Review, Read via API, Pull Request
gaps: No mention of mailbox system I proposed
Different communication expectations than I initially assumed

next_steps: 1. Align my communication approach with documented flow
2. Use GitHub Issues as primary communication channel
3. Expect Pull Requests for code review
5. Use TaskData wrapper for non-Sendable content

improvements_to_my_approach.current_approach: Sending messages via mailbox and GitHub Issues
adjustments_needed: Focus more on GitHub Issues for task assignment
Expect Pull Requests for code submissions
Use documented message types and labels
Follow the communication flow: Issue → PR → Review
